MANAGEMENT: Avoid changes in moisture/hydrologic conditions at the site. Changes could result from overstory removal, stream/wetland alteration or impacts due to erosion.

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: Early April to late June.
DIAGCHARS: This wetland yellow-flowered buttercup has hollow stems and may be erect or reclined and rooting the nodes.  It has leaves entire (without lobes) and serrate.  The upper leaves may be linear/lanceolate and they are 5-16 cm long and 1-3.5 cm wide.  The petiole is winged and sheathing the stem.
HABITAT: Sloughs, swamps and pond margins.
MANAGEMENT: Avoid changes in moisture/hydrologic conditions at the site.  Changes could result from overstory removal, stream/wetland alteration or vegetation removal that would result in increased erosion. Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species and should be removed. Avoid creating access to the site through trail or road construction.

FLOWERING_PERIOD:
Flowering Period: Early May to late June.
Fruiting Period: Early June to late July.
DIAGCHARS: This sedge is in the section Stellulatae. The stems are densely tufted. Leaves are plicate to flat, 1-4 mm wide, and shorter than the inflorescence. Achenes are lenticular (shaped like a lens) rather than 3-sided and the perigynia are thickened at the base. This is a plant of wet woodlands in Kentucky is associated with seeps and springs.
HABITAT: Alluvial and wet woods (Jones 2005).
MANAGEMENT: Avoid changes in moisture/hydrologic conditions at the site. Changes could result from overstory removal, stream/wetland alteration or impacts due to erosion.

FLOWERING_PERIOD:
Flowering Period: Early February to late March.
Fruiting Period: Early March to late April.
DIAGCHARS: Annual plants with leaves on the stem but mostly basal, lateral stems leafless. Fruits are flat and unwinged, strigulose (hairs all pointing in same direction), 6-11 mm long and 1.5-2 mm wide, the apex blunt. Flowers are white and about 4 mm across.
HABITAT: Dry rocky or sandy soil, cedar glades including disturbed sites.
MANAGEMENT: Woody plant invasion may need to be controlled using periodic prescribed fire, mowing or other means.  Timber removal may be beneficial. Hand removal of trees in the vicinity is needed to maintain the open character of the habitat for this species. Soil disturbance such as ATV trails or timber removal or any activity that results in increased erosion and weed invasion will be detrimental.  Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species.

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: Early April to late May.
DIAGCHARS: Similar to other dwarf dandelions but with all basal leaves and the a single flower on each stem.  There are 5-8  phyllaries (the bracts beneath the flower head)  and these are erect on fruit.  Also the pappus (the hairs at the top of the achene)  are 1.2-3 mm long.
HABITAT: Barrens and rocky woods.
MANAGEMENT: May tolerate some timber removal if done without excessive soil disturbance (disking/chopping) and if immediate vicinity of plant is protected from debris and direct cutting etc. Woody plant invasion may need to be controlled using periodic prescribed fire, mowing or other means to maintain the open character of the habitat for this species.  Hand removal of trees in the vicinity of the species is necessary.  Soil disturbance resulting from activities such as ATV trails, timber removal or any activity that results in increased erosion and weed invasion will be detrimental.  Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species and should be removed

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: Early June to late July.
DIAGCHARS: This variety is smaller than var hisspidissimum and has leaves to 2 cm wide. The fruit does not have a collar and are smooth and shiny.Corolla tubular, regular, dull yellowish white, the lobes erect and acute. Ovary deeply 4 parted. Anthers included. Style long exsert.
HABITAT: Sandy, gravelly, or rocky prairies, glades, and open woods.
MANAGEMENT: Woody plant invasion may need to be controlled using periodic prescribed fire, mowing or other means to maintain the open character of the habitat for this species.  Hand removal of trees in the vicinity of the species is necessary.  Soil disturbance resulting from activities such as ATV trails, timber removal or any activity that results in increased erosion and weed invasion will be detrimental.  Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species and should be removed.

HABITAT: Occurs on river bluffs and is also reported from rocky glades and open ground.
MANAGEMENT: The habitat where this species is found would likely be detrimentally impacted by logging, both of the steep slopes themselves, the forest along the cliffline.  Even forestry activities at the base of the bluff could destabilize this senstive steep land.

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: Early July to late September.
DIAGCHARS: Aquatic plant occurring in quiet waters (ponds) with cauline leaves that are slender (ca 1.3 mm wide), flaccid, sharply serrulate and 1-nerved. They are arranged in whorls of 3 or are opposite and the upper ones are not closely over-lapping.  The staminate spathe is smaller(2-4 mm) and sessile and then separating from plant and floating.  There are 9 stamens.  It is interesting to note that this plant has become invasive in some parts of Europe; it has spread to become locally weedy in eutrophic waters.
HABITAT: Ponds, cool waters of spring branches, stream margins, sloughs.
MANAGEMENT: Avoid changes in moisture/hydrologic conditions at the site.  Changes could result from overstory removal, stream/wetland alteration or impacts due to erosion. Exotec pest plants are a threat and should be removed.

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: Early July to late September.
GLOBAL_GENDESC: A perennial herb that grows from a single tuber.  The light green stem is smooth and often reaches a height of 60 cm.  White flowers grow in loose, round to elongate cluster at the top of the stem.  There are normally 6-15 flowers in each cluster.  The flower petals are oblong, 7 mm long and 2.5 mm wide; the lowermost ""lip"" petal is narrow at the top and broad at its base and is about 13 mm long and 3 mm wide.  The edges of the petals are wavy but smooth.  A thin spur, 4-5 cm long, curves forward from behind the ""lip"" petal.  The species has 2-3 large leaves with bases that loosely wrap around the lower portion of the stem.  These leaves are long and narrow (20 cm long, 3 cm wide) with a smooth edge.  The leaves higher up the stem are much smaller.  The fruit is ellipsoid, about 15 mm long and 3 mm wide.  Seeds are released when the fruit dries and its walls break open  (Shea 1992; Fernald 1970; Gleason and Cronquist 1991; Bailey 2001).
GRANGECOM: Occurrs on the Appalachian Plateaus of Kentucky, Tennessee, and Alabama, the Coastal Plain of Alabama and Mississippi, the Blue Ridge Province of Georgia , North Carolina (Historic), and Tennessee; the Ridge and Valley Province in Alabama, and the Piedmont of Georgia and South Carolina.
DIAGCHARS: The white fringeless orchid is a terrestrial orchid with white flowers clustered at the end of the flowering stem. The flowers lack fringing on the lip.
HABITAT: Partial shade or open seepage areas both wooded and herbaceous including swamps, floodplain forests, seepage slopes.
MANAGEMENT: The habitat for this species is especially sensitive to changes in hydrology and not likely to withstand much alteration.  Grazing or browsing pressure, vegetation removal, hydrologic changes (i.e. stream alterations road construction) would be detrimental. Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species and should be removed. Avoid creating access to the site through trail or road construction.
SOTHCONSID: A slender, erect, white-flowered perennial orchid, up to 6 dm tall. Growing in colonies from fleshy roots, usually with many sterile stems or leaves. The inflorescence a loose spike with up to 20 flowers. The spike round to short-oblong, 4-10 cm long and about 5 cm wide; lower bracts longest, gradually reduced upward. Flowers white, prominent, long-spurred, spreading-ascending, very fragrant in the evening.

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: Early August to late October.
DIAGCHARS: Similar to the common old field aster, S. priceae has purple flowers and larger flower heads. The rays are to 15 mm in length and there are often more than 70 flws in a head.
HABITAT: Rocky, gravelly or sandy soil.
MANAGEMENT: Disturbance such as ATV trails, timber removal or any activity that results in increased erosion and weed invasion will be detrimental.

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: Early August to mid November.
DIAGCHARS: There are several species of Prenanthes that are considered rare in Kentucky. P. alba is distinguished by have a cinnamon brown pappus. Also the inflorescence is glabrous and there are 8-18 flowers (fewer in P.altissima).
HABITAT: Open woodlands and thickets.
MANAGEMENT: Timber removal may be beneficial and even needed to maintain the open character of the habitat for this species. Hand removal of trees in the vicinity of the population is necessary to avoid impacts from timber operations. Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species and should be removed. Avoid creating access to the site through trail or road construction.

MANAGEMENT: Timber removal may be beneficial and even needed to maintain the open character of the habitat for this species. Hand removal of trees in the vicinity of the population is necessary to avoid impacts from timber operations. Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species and should be removed. Avoid creating access to the site through trail or road construction.

FLOWERING_PERIOD:
Flowering Period: Early April to late April.
Fruiting Period: Early October to late October.
GLOBAL_GENDESC: Juglans cinerea is a deciduous tree reaching nearly 100 ft. in height. Its bark is grayish-brown, with smooth ridges. The pith of the stems is transversely partitioned into chambers which are dark chocolate brown. The leaves are compound with 11-17 leaflets that have long, pointed tips. Leaflets from the middle of the leaf are the largest. The flowers are in dense, drooping catkins (resembling cats' tails) which protrude from the buds in autumn and lengthen in the spring. The nut resembles a short cylinder (1.5-2.75 inches long) with 2 halves and 2 or 4 ridges running end to end along its rough surface. Both the nut and the husk remain closed at maturity. Seed production begins when the tree has reached 20 years of age and peaks when it is 30-60 years old. Seeds are produced every year, but larger seed crops occur every 2-3 years. Germination of seeds usually takes place in the spring from seeds that fell the previous season. (Gleason and Cronquist 1991, Ostry et al. 1994).
GRANGECOM: Juglans cinerea occurs throughout the central and eastern United States and southeastern Canada (Fernald 1950, Smith 1988, Brown and Kirkman 1990, Gleason and Cronquist 1991, TNC HO 1992).
DIAGCHARS: Gray scaly bark and leaves divided into 11-17 leaflets; the terminal or end leaflet is present (and usually absent in black walnut).  White walnut has twigs with leaf scars with a hairy ridge
HABITAT: Mesic wooded ravines and alluvial forests.
MANAGEMENT: Timber removal would be detrimental.

The pith of the stems is transversely partitioned into chambers which are dark chocolate brown. The leaves are compound with 11-17 leaflets that have long, pointed tips. Leaflets from the middle of the leaf are the largest. The flowers are in dense, drooping catkins (resembling cats' tails) which protrude from the buds in autumn and lengthen in the spring. The nut resembles a short cylinder (1.5-2.75 inches long) with 2 halves and 2 or 4 ridges running end to end along its rough surface. Both the nut and the husk remain closed at maturity. Seed production begins when the tree has reached 20 years of age and peaks when it is 30-60 years old. Seeds are produced every year, but larger seed crops occur every 2-3 years. Germination of seeds usually takes place in the spring from seeds that fell the previous season. (Gleason and Cronquist 1991, Ostry et al. 1994).
GRANGECOM: Juglans cinerea occurs throughout the central and eastern United States and southeastern Canada (Fernald 1950, Smith 1988, Brown and Kirkman 1990, Gleason and Cronquist 1991, TNC HO 1992).
DIAGCHARS: Gray scaly bark and leaves divided into 11-17 leaflets; the terminal or end leaflet is present (and usually absent in black walnut).  White walnut has twigs with leaf scars with a hairy ridge
HABITAT: Mesic wooded ravines and alluvial forests.
MANAGEMENT: Timber removal would be detrimental.

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: Mid August to late October.
GRANGECOM: Narrow distribution, in 3 Kentucky cos.: Menifee, Powell and Wolf. The range of this species is a part of the Daniel Boone National Forest, in the Red River Gorge area.
DIAGCHARS: This goldenrod has white hairs on the stem. It is somewhat similar to S. flexicaulis in having ovate to elliptic shaped leaves distributed along the stem; the base is more subcordate (slightly heart-shaped). It is found in rockhouses and along rocky ledges.
HABITAT: Sandstone rockhouses and ledges along clifflines.
MANAGEMENT: Timber removal would be detrimental. Disturbance such as ATV trails, timber removal or any activity that results in increased erosion and weed invasion will be detrimental. A buffer along the cliffline above these forested slopes is needed.

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: Early July to late September.
DIAGCHARS: This species is distinguished by the copious glands on the achenes and the leaves have a viscid (sticky) underside.  The sharply toothed (albeit few toothed)  leaves are cauline (on the stem) and are over 6 cm long and 2 cm wide. The heads are corymbiform with white to pink rays (the outer flowers in the head).  It is restricted to the Cumberland Mountains.
HABITAT: Moist sand in mesophytic forest, wet openings along stream on dip slope.
MANAGEMENT: Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species and should be removed. Avoid creating access to the site through trail or road construction.

FLOWERING_PERIOD:
Flowering Period: Mid April to mid June.
Fruiting Period: Early June to late July.
DIAGCHARS: Herbaceous mint with opposite, ovate-oblong (to 20 cm) leaves in 2 to 3 pairs, usually near the base of the inflorescence, giving a whorled apppearance. The pink-tinged flowers (0.6-0.8 inches long) are in a single terminal panicle. They are bilabiate (two-lipped) and the lower lip is fringed; four stamens present. It flowers earlier than C. canadensis (Apr-Jun versus Jul-Sep) and it can extend into drier woods (Campbell, 2012).
HABITAT: Rich forests, ranging from moist forests to rather dry oak forests (Weakley 1998).
MANAGEMENT: Avoid changes in moisture/hydrologic conditions at the site.  Changes could result from overstory removal, stream/wetland alteration or impacts due to erosion. Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species. Avoid creating access to the site through trail or road construction.

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: May-June.
DIAGCHARS: The flowers are swollen on one side of the base and generally yellowish green (rather than orangish).  Leaves are glaucous on the lower side (below) and green above.  A glandular hypanthium distinguishes it  from other varieties .
HABITAT: Moist woods and thickets, associated with limestone derived soils.
MANAGEMENT: Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species.

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: Early May to late June.
DIAGCHARS: Leaves are cauline (on the stem), 2 or 3 in number, cordate (heartshape) and clasping.  Flowers are terminal with 4 white spreading tepals, the perianth (petals and sepals together) 1-3 mm long.  Fruit is pale red.
HABITAT: Moist mesophytic woods, mountain and stream terraces, mesic rock faces, and recent clearings.
MANAGEMENT: Timber removal would be detrimental. Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species and should be removed. Avoid creating access to the site through trail or road construction.

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: Early May to late July.
GRANGECOM: Throughout much of Canada, and in the U.S. from Maine south to the mountains of northern Georgia, and northwestwards to Washington (USDA-NRCS 1999). Ten extant locations are known from Missouri (Missouri Department of Conservation). It is reported from four counties in Kentucky (Kentucky Natural Heritage Program). It is found in all counties in Maine (Maine Natural Areas Program). In Indiana this species is found throughout the northern part of the state and in one location in the southeast (Ind
DIAGCHARS: Stemless perennial herb, rhizomatous, scapose (the flowering stem and leaves arising from the rhizome). The petiole erect to 5 dm and the leaves are ternate (divided into three), each division pinnately 3-5 foliate. Leaflets are lance-elliptic generally, finely serrate and about 15 cm long. The lateral leaflets are assymetric at the base. Fruit is black.
HABITAT: Mesic forests.
MANAGEMENT: Disturbance such as ATV trails, timber removal or any activity that results in increased erosion and weed invasion will be detrimental.  Some pressure from the medicinal plant trade exists.

FLOWERING_PERIOD:
Flowering Period: Early June to late July.
Fruiting Period: Early August to late October.
DIAGCHARS: This lily has flowers that are erect rather than nodding. The tepals are abruptly narrowed near the base (clawed).  It is found on woodland borders or associated with grass dominated areas.
HABITAT: Openings in seasonally moist forests, prairies and roadsides.
MANAGEMENT: Grazing or browsing pressure (including whitetail deer) and hydrologic changes (i.e. stream alterations road construction) would very likely be detrimental to the habitat for this species.  Collection pressure should also be considered in planning access to the areas where this species occurs. Woody plant invasion may need to be controlled using periodic prescribed fire or other means to maintain the open character of the habitat for this species.  Hand removal of trees in the vicinity of the species may be needed.  Soil disturbance or any activity that results in increased erosion and weed invasion would very likely be detrimental.  Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species.

DIAGCHARS: This lily has flowers that are erect rather than nodding. The tepals are abruptly narrowed near the base (clawed).  It is found on woodland borders or associated with grass dominated areas.
HABITAT: Openings in seasonally moist forests, prairies and roadsides.
MANAGEMENT: Grazing or browsing pressure (including whitetail deer) and hydrologic changes (i.e. stream alterations road construction) would very likely be detrimental to the habitat for this species.  Collection pressure should also be considered in planning access to the areas where this species occurs. Woody plant invasion may need to be controlled using periodic prescribed fire or other means to maintain the open character of the habitat for this species.  Hand removal of trees in the vicinity of the species may be needed.  Soil disturbance or any activity that results in increased erosion and weed invasion would very likely be detrimental.  Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species.

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: Early July to late August.
DIAGCHARS: Large (7-15 dm) perennial with narrow to broadly oblanceolate  leaves. Stem pubescent and unbranched.  Flowers are dark maroon, 6-9 mm, in a terminal panicle and the rachis pubescent.  Tepals are tapering and without glands.
HABITAT: Rich dry or mesic woods.
MANAGEMENT: Disturbance such as ATV trails, timber removal or any activity that results in increased erosion and weed invasion will be detrimental.

FLOWERING_PERIOD:
Flowering Period: Early July to late September.
Fruiting Period: Early July to late August.
DIAGCHARS: The lower leaf blades and sheaths of this bulrush are purplish and the top of the culm is scabrous. Also, stems do not come from the ground in clusters but as single stems. The styles are divided into 3 parts (trifid). Scales in the inflorescence are dark (brown to black) with a green midstripe. Spikelets are not obviously drooping.
HABITAT: Swamps, bogs and streamsides.
MANAGEMENT: Avoid changes in moisture/hydrologic conditions at the site.  Changes could result from overstory removal, stream/wetland alteration or vegetation removal that would result in increased erosion.

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: Early August to late October.
DIAGCHARS: The flowers are yellowish white and appear as a long tube. The plants are glabrous (without hair). The length of the calyx lobes are less than 1.5 cm, ovate to deltoid in shape and keeled on the back.
HABITAT: Reported in meadows and damp woods; in KY, prairies and open woodlands.
MANAGEMENT: Woody plant invasion may need to be controlled using periodic prescribed fire, mowing or other means to maintain the open character of the habitat for this species. Hand removal of trees in the vicinity of the plants is needed. Soil disturbance such as ATV trails or timber removal or any activity that results in increased erosion and weed invasion will be detrimental.  Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species and should be removed.

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: Early September to late October.
DIAGCHARS: The spike of white flowers is tightly spiraled, appearing in several ranks rather than a simple single spiral.  Leaves present at flowering.  The flowers are light yellow (not deeply colored). The lateral sepals ascend and are 7.5 mm long/  The lip is arcuate recurved (arched up and then the tip down) and with an erose or wavy margin.
HABITAT: Damp (although sometimes seasonally only)  acid soil of open woods and grassy openings.
MANAGEMENT: Avoid changes in moisture/hydrologic conditions at the site.  Changes could result from overstory removal, stream/wetland alteration or vegetation removal that would result in increased erosion.

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: Early August to late September.
DIAGCHARS: This small (1-4 dm) plant of wet prairies and sphagnum bogs has opposite (as opposed to alternate in B. paniculata) leaves that are reduced to scales along the stem.  Petals are oblong, denticulate and abruptly narrowed to  rounded with a minute tip (mucro).
HABITAT: Bogs, swamps, savannas (Weakley 2011); dry or wet acid soil;  in KY, mossy seeps.
MANAGEMENT: Timber removal may be beneficial. Hand removal of trees in the vicinity is needed to maintain the open character of the habitat for this species. Soil disturbing could cause increased erosion and be detrimental. Changes in moisture/hydrologic conditions of the habitat for this species would likely be detrimental. Changes could result from overstory removal, stream/wetland alteration or impacts due to erosion or soil deposition. Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species.

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: Mid March to late May.
GRANGECOM: Arkansas, northern Lousiana, central Alabama, Kansas, Missouri, Mississippi, Oklahoma, Tennessee, Texas; disjunct in southern Ohio.
DIAGCHARS: Yellow flowers are erect  and the tepals (the """"petals"""") do not have red or red/brown spots.   The inner tepals have noticeable auricles at the base.  The extended style (bearing the stigma) persists to form a long beak on the fruit.
HABITAT: Mesic ravine forests.
MANAGEMENT: Disturbance of surrounding areas such as ATV trails, timber removal or any activity that results in increased erosion and weed invasion will be detrimental. Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species and should be removed. Avoid creating access to the site through trail or road construction.

GRANGECOM: Arkansas, northern Lousiana, central Alabama, Kansas, Missouri, Mississippi, Oklahoma, Tennessee, Texas; disjunct in southern Ohio.
DIAGCHARS: Yellow flowers are erect  and the tepals (the """"petals"""") do not have red or red/brown spots.   The inner tepals have noticeable auricles at the base.  The extended style (bearing the stigma) persists to form a long beak on the fruit.
HABITAT: Mesic ravine forests.
MANAGEMENT: Disturbance of surrounding areas such as ATV trails, timber removal or any activity that results in increased erosion and weed invasion will be detrimental. Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species and should be removed. Avoid creating access to the site through trail or road construction.

FLOWERING_PERIOD:
Flowering Period: Early April to late August.
Fruiting Period: Early July to late November.
GRANGECOM: Baptisia tinctoria grows from Ontario and New England into the southern United States.
DIAGCHARS: This species can reach 1-3 feet in height and has clover-like leaves, and yellow flowers (Foster and Duke 1990). Racemes are numerous and leaves tend to be dark bluish-green (Rhoads and Block 2000).  Leaves are widely branched with leaflets 1-3 (sometimes to 4) cm long, inflorescences numerous, the flowers yellow and 8-16 mm long, pods small 8-15 m.
HABITAT: Sandhills, pine flatwoods, xeric woodlands, ridges, woodland edges, and roadbanks (Weakley 2011).
MANAGEMENT: Timber removal to maintain the open character of the habitat for this species may be beneficial but careful review of the implementation of this practice is needed. Removal of trees in the vicinity of the population of this species may be warranted. Soil disturbing activities that results in increased erosion or weed invasion will be detrimental. Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species.
SOTHCONSID: Reaches 1-3 feet in height and has clover-like leaves, and yellow flowers (Foster and Duke 1990). Racemes are numerous and leaves tend to be dark bluish-green (Rhoads and Block 2000).

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: Early June to late September.
GLOBAL_GENDESC: Perennial herb.
DIAGCHARS: The orange/yellow flowers distinguish this species from most other orchids.  The lip is fringed and the spur is long (18-28 mm). The lower leaves are narrow (less than 2 cm), strap-like and up to 20 cm in length.   Platantheras in general have the upper two petals merged into a hood that extends over the column.  The lateral sepals area spreading.
HABITAT: Dry to moist open soil, thickets, woods, and bogs, moist open ephemeral streamheads, pond margins.
MANAGEMENT: The habitat for this species is especially sensitive to changes in hydrology and not likely to withstand much alteration.  Grazing or browsing pressure, vegetation removal, hydrologic changes (i.e. stream alterations road construction) would be detrimental. Exotic pest plants are a threat to this species and should be removed. Avoid creating access to the site through trail or road construction.

FLOWERING_PERIOD: Flowering Period: May and June.
DIAGCHARS: Zigzag iris is distinguished from other blue iris species by its short flowering stems, which are shorter than the leaves (to 35 cm) and often hidden among the leaves. Also the ovary and capsule are 6-angled (Jones 2005).
HABITAT: Forested and open wetlands, shorelines.
MANAGEMENT: Changes in wetland hydrology or disturbance, parituclarly along the shoreline, would likely be detrimental to this species.  Methods of herbicide application should be carefully reviewed for potential impacts.
